choices.text: Level 4 cervical lymph node is earliest to be involved
Radiotherapy is the treatment of choice
May be associated with unilateral serous otitis media

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with right side neck mass since 4 months. Biopsy was done which suggestive of non keratinizing undifferentiated carcinoma. CT scan was done which showed presence of soft tissue mass arising from Lateral wall of nasopharynx. Nasal endoscopy was done picture is given below. What is not True about this condition?
questions.solution:
The most common carcinoma of nasopharynx is the squamous cell carcinoma.

The most common site of origin is the fossa of rosenmuller. Just behind the bulge of Eustachian tube cartilage.

Etiology of nasopharyngeal carcinoma includes genetic causes, environmental causes such as exposure to nitrosamines and polycyclic hydrocarbons, and infection of Epstein- Barr virus. (Option D)

Clinical features:

Nearly 75 % cases of patients present with painless cervical lymphadenopathy of mainly upper deep cervical lymph nodes (level 2) and posterior triangle of neck level 5. (Option A)

The other symptoms of nasopharyngeal mass include nasal obstruction, hyponasal voice, unilateral serous otitis media , diplopia and ophthalmoplegia. (Option C)

Treatment Because of difficulty in obtaining surgical margins, the definitive treatment of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is radiotherapy or in later stages with concurrent chemotherapy. (Option B )

Key Takeaway

Nasopharyngeal Carcinoma

  • Aw EBV, From Fossa of Rosenmuller
  • Presentation - Painless Cervical Lymphadenopathy level 2 / UL SOM
  • Management - Radiotherapy / Concurrent Chemoradiation in later stages.

Image reference: springer link website.

choices.text: It arises from posterior wall of hypopharynx.
It should be managed by excision
It arises due to traction from outside the esophagus.

questions.text: A 70-year-old elderly male presents with a history of dysphagia since 1 month. Dysphagia is associated halitosis, regurgitation of food, and coughing. Barium swallow was done in this patient, picture is given below. All of the following is true about this condition except?
questions.solution:
The picture of Barium swallow shown above is suggestive of Zenker's diverticulum.

Diverticulum is an outpouching from a tubular structure. It forms when there is neuromuscular incoordination while swallowing.

In hypopharynx, the most common site of its formation is the Killian dehiscence, which lies between the thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus , parts of inferior constrictive muscle.

It arises from posterior wall hence it is also called posterior pouch. (Option A)

It is a pulsing diverticulum as it occurs due to increase in intraluminal pressure. (Option D)

A true diverticulum contains all the layers of wall, but zenker's diverticulum contains only mucosa hence it is a false diverticulum. (Option B)

Main management of zenker's diverticulum is excision of pouch, Endoscopic stapling diverticulotomy. (Option C)

Key Takeaway :

Zenker Diverticulum is Pulsing False diverticulum caused due to increased intraluminal pressure in the Posterior wall of hypopharynx. Managed with excision & Endoscopic stapling diverticulotomy.

Image reference: radiopedia.

choices.text: Sinus of Morgagni- Tensor veli palatine
Space of Gillette - retropharyngeal lymph nodes.

questions.text: The wall of the pharynx consists of Muscle layer. A gap exists between the superior constrictor and the base of skull. What is the name of this gap and which structure passes through this gap?
questions.solution:
The muscular layer of pharynx is made up of inner longitudinal and outer circular muscle layers.

The outer circular muscle layer contains three muscles namely superior, middle and inferior constrictor muscles.

The upper border of the superior constrictor is not directly attached to the base of skull, a gap exists between the two and this gap is filled only by pharyngobasilar fascia. This gap is known as sinus of Morgagni.

The following structures passes through this gap (mnemonic: TAALA)

  1. Tensor veli palatini.
  2. Ascending pharyngeal artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal artery's pharyngeal branch
  4. Levator veli palatini
  5. Auditory tube (Eustachian tube)

Key Takeaway :

The following structures pass through sinus of Morgagni (mnemonic: TAALA)

  1. Tensor veli palatini.
  2. Ascending pharyngeal artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal artery's pharyngeal branch
  4. Levator veli palatini
  5. Auditory tube (Eustachian tube)

Image reference: Earth lab website.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with recurrent URTI with mouth breathing and snoring. His x-ray lateral view is given below. The child was advised adenoidectomy. Child can develop all the following complications due to this surgery except ?
questions.solution:
Adenoid occupies the nasopharynx thus, hypertrophy of adenoid will lead to reduced flow of air coming from vocal cords to outside, which leads to Hypo nasality of voice.

After adenoidectomy the air flow from vocal cords going outside will improve leading to Hyper nasality of voice. (option A)

Other complications of adenoidectomy include Haemorrhage, velopharyngeal insufficiency. (Option B & C)

A rare complication is Grisel syndrome, which is inflammatory subluxation of the Atlanto axial joint . (Option D)

Contraindications of adenoidectomy include Acute infection  and bleeding disorders.

Key Takeaway :

Adenoidectomy Complications :

  • Hyper nasality of voice
  • Haemorrhage
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency
  • Grisel Syndrome

Image reference: Radiopedia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient presented with complain of increased sensitivity of oral cavity to spicy and hot food. On examination, roughness was felt in oral mucosa and white lacy striae were seen. Picture given below. It was associated with skin lesions on the flexor surface of wrist, thigh and forearm. What is the name given to this striae marks?
questions.solution:
Based on the photograph shown above and clinical presentation described the above, lesion is suggestive of oral lichen planus.

It appears as a white lacy striae in the oral cavity which is known as Wickham's striae. In this condition patient often complain of increased sensitivity of oral cavity mucosa to hot and spicy foods. The erosive lichen planus is very painful.

It is often associated with skin lesions which are described as purple, pruritus, planar, polygonal, papules. Mnemonic 5P.

The treatment is topical steroids.

Key Takeaway :

Oral lichen planus appears as a white lacy striae in the oral cavity, which is known as Wickham's striae.

Image reference: Science direct website.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents with complain of severe throat pain, fever since 2 days. He also developed trismus since 1 day. On examination of the oral cavity left side tonsil was pushed medially. Picture Is given below. The best treatment in this condition is ?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture shown above, it is suggestive of peritonsillar abscess. It is also known as Quinsy.

The peritonsillar space lies between a capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle. Any abscess in this space is called peritonsillar abscess.

It usually spreads from Tonsils. Mainly caused by mixed aerobic ( Group A beta hemolytic streptococcus) and anaerobic organisms.

Clinical features include painful swallowing, trismus, hot potato voice, pain in ear fever, malaise.

Management : incision and drainage is the mainstay of treatment. The incision is given just lateral to where a vertical line drawn from anterior border of anterior pillar meets a horizontal line passing through the base of uvula. (Option B)

Antibiotics mostly betalactum group along with metronidazole is given to cover aerobes and anaerobes, respectively. Although Antibiotics alone is not sufficient. (Option C)

Tonsillectomy is performed after 6 weeks of episode.

Key Takeaway :

Quinsy Management :

  • Intraoral Incision and Drainage
  • Antibiotics (Aerobic & Anaerobic)
  • Interval Tonsillectomy

Image reference: Academic life in Emergency medicine website.

questions.text: Given below is the CECT showing an enhancing mass in the nose, sphenopalatine fossa and infratemporal fossa. The patient is 18-year-old male presenting with recurrent epistaxis, nasal obstruction, and swelling of cheek. He should be managed by all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and Ct scan findings, it can be said that the diagnosis in this case is Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

It is the most common benign lesion of the nasopharynx. It is almost exclusively seen in young males.

Clinical presentation includes recurrent epistaxis, unilateral nasal obstruction, Frog face deformity.

Main investigation in this condition is CT PNS with brain cuts with contrast. Biopsy is contraindicated in this condition due to the highly vascular nature of the mass. ( Option D )

Treatment includes surgical excision, various surgical approaches includes Endoscopic approach, medial maxillectomy by lateral rhinotomy approach, transpalatine & sub palatine approach, infratemporal approach, trans maxillary approach. ( Option A )

Since it is a very vascular tumour Preoperative embolization to the feeding vessel is also indicated in this condition. ( Option C )

Radiotherapy is only indicated after surgical excision only in intracranial cases to achieve clearance. Not given Preoperatively. ( Option B )

Key Takeaway:

Juvenile Angiofibroma -

  • Biopsy C/I & Pre Operative Embolization done: Due to Highly Vascular Tumor.
  • Surgical Excision Mainstay
  • Radiotherapy for Intracranial extension only Post Surgery.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: Patient with multicentric, multifocal, and microscopic differentiated thyroid malignancy.
Patient with I 131 concentrating in distant metastasis.
All patients with follicular, papillary and mixed carcinoma of more than 1.5 cm in size, with or without capsular invasion.
Medullary carcinoma thyroid with capsular invasion.

questions.text: A 35-year-old female patient underwent hemi thyroidectomy, postoperative histopathology report suggested that the nodule was showing signs of carcinoma. She was advised to undergo radioiodine I131 ablation. All of the following are the indications for radioiodine ablation therapy, except ?
questions.solution:
Selection of patient for radio iodine ablation:

  • Patient with I 131 concentrating in distant metastasis. (Option B)
  • Patient with multicentric, multifocal, and microscopic differentiated thyroid malignancy. (Option A)
  • All patients with follicular, papillary and mixed carcinoma of more than 1.5 cm in size, with or without capsular invasion. (Option C)
  • Patient with residual thyroid disease in which revision surgery is not possible.

Who should not be ablated:

  • Patient with low risk factors including papillary carcinoma with tumor size 1 to 1.5 cm with no capsular invasion or distant metastasis.
  • Patient with medullary carcinoma because they are based on parafollicular C cells which cannot concentrate radioiodine. Hence, they are treated with 131 I labelled meta iodo benzyl guanidine (MIBG). (Option D)

Key Takeaway :

Patients with medullary carcinoma which contains parafollicular C cells can't concentrate radioiodine. Hence, they are not treated with radioiodine ablation therapy.

choices.text: It is the lateral channel for passage for food
It is the most common site for carcinoma in Plummer Vinson syndrome.
It is the site for foreign body lodgement.
The internal laryngeal nerve lies sub mucosal intense area.

questions.text: The endoscopic picture of a part of hypopharynx is shown in the picture given below. Which of the following sentences is not true regarding the anatomical structure which is shown in the picture given below?
questions.solution:
The anatomical structure shown in this Endoscopic picture is Pyriform fossa. It is a part of hypopharynx.

Hypopharynx is made up of three parts: post cricoid area , pyriform fossa and posterior pharyngeal wall. Out of these parts carcinoma due to Plummer Vinson syndrome is commonly seen in post cricoid area. ( Option B )

Significance of Pyriform fossa :

  1. They form the lateral channel for the passage of food. (Option A)
  2. They are the common site of lodgement of foreign body. (Option C)
  3. The internal laryngeal nerve lies very superficially (sub mucosal). (Option D)
  4. Pyriform fossa has the richest lymphatic supply.

Key Takeaway :

Plummer Vinson Syndrome : Arises from Postcricoid Area

  • Triad of Iron deficiency anemia + Dysphagia + Esophageal web

Image reference: Clinical endoscopy website.

questions.text: A 6-year-old female malnourished patient presented with complain of throat pain and fever. On examination of oral cavity tonsil shows presence of ulcer and greyish black membrane. Picture Is shown below. Which of the following antibiotics should be used in this case?
questions.solution:
Based on the picture shown above the diagnosis in this case is Vincent's angina. It is also known as trench mouth.

This is an Acute necrotizing ulcerative lesion caused by Borrelia Vincenti (spirochete) and F.fusiformis (anaerobe).

The infection starts in the interdental papillae and then spreads to the surface of gingiva and tonsil forming the ulcer and greyish black necrotic membrane.

Management is penicillin and metronidazole.

Key Takeaway :

Vincent's Angina Management :

Penicillin ( Covers Spirochete ) & Metronidazole ( Covers Anaerobes )

questions.text: A 12-year-old unimmunised girl presents with sore throat fever and pain in the throat. Throat examination reveals membrane over tonsils, which bleed on removal as shown in the picture below. Most probable diagnosis in this case is?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical picture and symptoms the diagnosis in this case is diphtheria

Diphtheria is a bacterial infection of pharynx . It is caused by cyanobacteria diphtheriae. That mainly occurs in unimmunized population

It is an airborne infection which releases toxin which leads to necrosis resulting in mucosal ulcers.

Fibrinogen suppurative exudate forms over the ulcer forming a pseudomembrane . This membrane is dirty grey in appearance .

The removal of the membrane causes bleeding. Management aims to neutralize neurotoxin and prevent it's further progression. Beta lactam and macrolides should be started immediately .

Key Takeaway :

Diphtheria Characteristics

  • unimmunised Child
  • High Fever, Sore Throat with Pseudomembrane which bleeds on removal.
  • Managed with Betalactam & Macrolides

Ddx of Whitish Membrane over tonsil :

  • Diphtheria - High Fever Sore Throat with Pseudomembrane which bleeds on removal.
  • Vincent's Angina - Low Grade Fever. Ulcerative Growth
  • Candida - Can be Rubbed off.
  • Oral Hairy leukoplakia - Can't be Rubbed off.

Image reference: Wikimedia lecture website.

choices.text: Abscess lies behind the prevertebral fascia.
Involves both submandibular and sublingual spaces.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male patient with dysphagia and difficulty in breathing. On examination there is a bulge of posterior pharyngeal wall confined to right side of the midline. His x-ray neck lateral view is given. Which of the following is true about the condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and x-ray picture the diagnosis is retropharyngeal abscess.

Although option A cannot be ruled out just based on x-ray but clinical features are suggestive of retropharyngeal abscess. Moreover in pre vertebral abscess, the bulge is seen in the midline of posterior pharyngeal wall.

It can be acute and chronic . Acute infection is commonly seen in children and chronic in adults.

Clinical feature it presents with Dysphagia, stridor , tortillas. Examination reveals unilateral bulge in the posterior pharyngeal wall- one side of the midline .

This feature differentiates prevertebral abscess, in which a midline diffuse bulge is seen.

X-ray neck lateral view shows increased prevertebral space .

Management is Incision and drainage , antibiotics and anti tubercular therapy if necessary.

Key Takeaway :

Retropharyngeal Abscess

  • UL bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Managed with Incision & drainage with antibiotics.

Image reference: Radiopedia.

choices.text: Uses ultrasonic energy to vibrate its blade at 55,000 cycles per second. The vibration transfers energy to the tissue, providing simultaneous cutting and coagulation.
Tissue is removed by a repeated process of freezing and thawing.
It is a powered rotatory shaving device with continuous Suction.
It converts the conductive saline solution into ionized plasma layer resulting in molecular thermal dissection with minimal transfer of thermal energy.

questions.text: A 9-year-old female patient had chronic tonsillitis. She was advised Coblation assisted tonsillectomy. The intraoperative picture is given below. What is the principle of coblation technology?
questions.solution:
The above equipment shown in the figure is a Coblation wand.

The entire equipment contains a Radiofrequency generator, foot control, saline irrigation and the Coblation wand.

It converts the conductive saline solution into ionized plasma layer resulting in molecular thermal dissection with minimal transfer of thermal energy. (Option D)

Cryotherapy uses extremely cold temperature. And repeated freezing and thawing cycles. (Option B)

Microdebrider is a powered rotatory shaving device with continuous Suction. (Option C)

Harmonic scalpel uses ultrasonic energy to vibrate its blade at 55,000 cycles per second. The vibration transfers energy to the tissue, providing simultaneous cutting and coagulation.(Option A)

Key Takeaway:

Coblation band converts the conductive saline solution into an ionized plasma layer resulting in molecular thermal dissection with minimal transfer of thermal energy.

Image reference: Research gate.

questions.text: A 13-year-old male patient known case of Juvenile angiofibroma was presented. His CT Scan shows tumor in the nasal cavity with minimal extension into sphenopalatine foramen, sphenopalatine fossa and pterygomaxillary fossa. What will be the stage of his tumor according to the Sessions staging system?
questions.solution:
When Tumor Involves Pterygomaxillary fossa minimally it's classified as stage 2a.

  • Classification according to Session
  • Stage IA - Tumor limited to posterior nares and/or nasopharyngeal vault
  • Stage IB - Tumor involving posterior nares and/or nasopharyngeal vault with involvement of at least 1 paranasal sinus
  • Stage IIA - Minimal lateral extension into pterygomaxillary fossa
  • Stage IIB - Full occupation of pterygomaxillary fossa with or without superior erosion of orbital bones
  • Stage IIIA - Erosion of skull base (ie, middle cranial fossa/pterygoid base); minimal intracranial extension
  • Stage IIIB - Extensive intracranial extension with or without extension into cavernous sinus.

Key Takeaway :

choices.text: Treatment is surgical excision and marsupialization
It arises from sub mandibular gland

questions.text: A 25-year-old female patient presented with a bluish, soft, cystic, fluctuant and translucent swelling located in the floor of the mouth. The clinical picture is given below. Which of the following statements about this condition is not true?
questions.solution:
Ranula are extravasation cyst (Option A) which originates from the sublingual glands in the floor of the mouth. (Option C)

They are of Two types: oral and cervical/plunging. (Option D)

They present as translucent bluish soft cystic swelling it resembles a Frog's belly.

Mnemonic Ranula - sublingual.

Treatment is surgical excision and marsupialization. (Option B)

Key Takeaway:

Plunging Ranula

  • extravasation cyst from sublingual gland
  • Translucent bluish soft swelling
  • Managed with excision & Marsupialization.

Image reference: Wikipedia.

questions.text: All of the following are the advantages of using robotic surgery in head and neck carcinoma except?
questions.solution:
The currently universally accepted system is the Da Vinci system.

The robot has a console in which the surgeon sits and operates, camera and instrumentation. The instruments are positioned trans orally.

Advantages of this system include limited blood loss, better visualization and magnification, avoidance of tracheostomy , equal result to open approach. ( Option A, B & D )

Disadvantages include cost of the instruments, need of adjuvant therapy in certain patients, increased learning curve. ( Option C )

Key Takeaway :

Although the Robotic System offers better Visualization, Magnification, Avoidance of tracheostomy & Open approach, it has a long learning curve.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female presented with complain of dysphagia to solids since 1 month. She is able to take semi solids and liquids. On blood investigation it was found that her haemoglobin was 6 gm%. Barium swallow was done picture given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical features and picture, the diagnosis is Patterson brown Kelly syndrome.

Patterson brown Kelly syndrome is also known as plummer Vinson syndrome. It is characterized by triad of post cricoid dysphagia, upper esophageal webs and iron deficiency anaemia.

Clinical features seen in 40 to 50 year female patients. Dysphagia first develops towards solids than to semi solids and liquids. Choking spells and aspiration occurs. Weakness, fatigue, and koilonychia may be seen.

5 to 10 percent chance of developing post cricoid carcinoma.

Diagnosis: Barium swallow shows upper oesophageal webs, biopsy shows epithelial atrophy, blood investigation shows iron deficiency anaemia.

Treatment Rigid esophagoscopy and dilatation of the web. Treatment of underlying anemia.

Key Takeaway:

Plummer Vinson syndrome / Patterson brown Kelly syndrome

  • triad of dysphagia, upper esophageal webs and iron deficiency anemia.
  • 5-10 % Patient Post Cricoid Carcinoma
  • Managed with Rigid Endoscopy and Dilatation.

Image reference: Research gate journal.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male who had been chewing tobacco for past 50 years, presents with a 6 months history of fungating soft papillary lesion in the oral cavity picture given below lymph nodes are not palpable. Biopsy from the lesion shows benign appearing papilloma with hyperkeratosis and acanthosis. Most likely diagnosis is ?
questions.solution:
Verrucous carcinoma is a low-grade SCC that appears as a cauliflower-like exophytic tumor.

There are three forms of verrucous carcinomas; all of them are recognized in areas of maceration.

Verrucous carcinoma of the oral cavity, known as oral florid papillomatosis, involves large areas of oral mucosa in elderly male tobacco chewers.

Verrucous carcinoma of the anogenital region, called giant cell condyloma of Buschke Löwenstein, occurs on the glans penis of young uncircumcised males and on the perianal region in both sexes.

Plantar verrucous carcinoma, also called epithelioma cuniculatum, usually involves the skin underlying the first metatarsal head, making numerous deep crypts filled with horny material and pus, and ultimately penetrates the plantar fascia.

Management is surgical excision with an appropriate margin of healthy tissue.

Key Takeaway :

Verrucous Carcinoma : low grade SCC

  • Giant cell condyloma
  • Papilloma with hyperkeratosis
  • Mx with Surgical Excision.

Image reference: Pathology outline website.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presented with complain of dysphagia to solids, regurgitation of food, halitosis since 1 month. Flexible oesophagoscopy was performed. Endoscopic picture is given below. He was advised to undergo Dohlman's procedure. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Dohlman's procedure is performed in Zenker's diverticulum.

Management of Zenker's diverticulum includes:

Excision of pouch: The pouch is excised and crico pharyngeal myotomy is done to relax the cricoid pharyngeal sphincter.

Endoscopic stapling of the diverticulotomy: This is presently preferred mode Of therapy. The surgery aims at converting the cricopharyngeal and pouch cavity into one single cavity to avoid collection of food.

This is achieved by cutting the cricopharyngeal bar. Historically it was first done by Dohlman. He used diathermy to achieve this.

Key Takeaway :

Zenker Diverticulum:

  • outpouching through Killian dehiscence
  • Boyce sign - Gurgling sound on pressing
  • Rx - Dolman procedure

Image reference: Mayo clinic.

choices.text: The prevertebral space lies between the prevertebral fascia anteriorly and vertebral bodies posteriorly.
Superiorly it extends up to skull base
The space is divided in midline by a raphe into two lateral space.
Inferiorly it extends down till the superior mediastinum.

questions.text: The picture given below shows diagram of prevertebral space. Which of the following statements regarding the prevertebral space is false?
questions.solution:
The prevertebral space is not divided in the midline hence any abscess in this space presents as a midline diffuse bulge of the posterior pharyngeal wall.

The retropharyngeal space is divided in the midline, forming two lateral spaces called as space of Gillette.

The pre vertebral space lies between the prevertebral fascia anteriorly and the vertebral bodies posteriorly.

Superiorly it extends up to the skull base and inferiorly it extends upto the superior mediastinum.

Key Takeaway :

Retropharyngeal Abscess

  • Divided by raphe into Space of Gillette.
  • UL bulge in posterior pharyngeal wall
  • Mx with Incision & drainage with antibiotics.

Image reference: Springer link.

choices.text: Weekly sub mucosal intralesional injections of steroids with hyaluronidase is used
The sub mucosal tissue is replaced by stiff fibrous tissue as it heals.
White lacy striae called Wickham's striae are seen in oral cavity.
It is a pre malignant condition

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presented with complain of inability to open the mouth completely. He was a pan masala addict. Examination of the oral cavity revealed the following findings as shown in the figure given below. Which of the following statement is false regarding this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the clinical presentation and the picture, the diagnosis in this case is oral sub mucous fibrosis.

It is a condition characterized by inflammation and fibrosis of the sub mucosal tissue (lamina propria and deeper connective tissue) inside the mouth.

It is due to chronic exposure of arecoline present in betel nuts. There is a progressive inability to open the mouth. The buccal cavity becomes blanched and stiff. (Option B)

It is Premalignant condition. (Option D)

Treatment if detected in early stages then cessation of betel nuts will be sufficient. Weekly sub mucosal intralesional injections can be used. (Option A) Surgical management includes releasing of the fibrous bands and repairing it with buccal fat pad.

The White lacy striae called Wickham's striae are seen in oral lichen and not in OSMF. (Option C)

Key Takeaway :

Oral Submucous Fibrosis

  • Inflammation & Fibrosis of submucosal tissue due to chronic arecoline exposure
  • Premalignant
  • Initially Managed with Steroid & Hyaluronidase Injection. Later with Surgical Release.

Image reference: Dentist channel online website.
